For integers $m,n\geq 1$, let $A(n,m)$ be the number of sequences $(a_1,\cdots,a_{nm})$ of integers satisfying the following two properties:\\

\begin{enumerate}
\item Each integer $k$ with $1\leq k\leq n$ occurs exactly $m$ times in the sequence $(a_1,\cdots,a_{nm})$.
\item If $i,j,$ and $k$ are integers such that $1\leq i\leq nm$ and $1\leq j\leq k\leq n$, then $j$ occurs in the sequence $(a_1,\cdots,a_i)$ at least as many times as $k$ does.
\end{enumerate}
For example, if $n=2$ and $m=5$, a possible sequence is $(a_1,\cdots,a_{10})=(1,1,2,1,2,2,1,2,1,2)$.  On the other hand, the sequence $(a_1,\cdots,a_{10})=(1,2,1,2,2,1,1,1,2,2)$ does not satisfy property (2) for $i=5$, $j=1$, and $k=2$.\\
\\
Prove that $A(n,m)=A(m,n)$.
